text: {{Infobox writer | name = Elizabeth Wurtzel | birth_name = Elizabeth Lee Wurtzel | image = Elizabeth Wurtzel BBF 2010 Shankbone.jpg | caption = Elizabeth Wurtzel in 2010. | birth_date = | birth_place = New York City, U.S. | death_date = | death_place = New York City, U.S. | occupation = Author, journalist, lawyer | spouse = | genre = Confessional memoir | notableworks = Prozac Nation | years_active = 1976—2020 | alma_mater = Harvard College (B.A.) Yale Law School (JD) }}Elizabeth Lee Wurtzel (July 31, 1967 - January 7, 2020) was an American feminist writer, essayist and journalist. She was known for publishing her best-selling memoir Prozac Nation, at the age of 27. Wurtzel wrote regularly for The Wall Street Journal. She was played by Christina Ricci in a movie based on her memoir in 2001. Wurtzel was born in New York City. She had a BA in comparative literature from Harvard College and a JD from Yale Law School. In 2015, she married James Freed. In February 2015, Wurtzel was diagnosed with breast cancer. She had a double mastectomy. Wurtzel died of meningitis caused by the cancer in New York City on January 7, 2020, aged 52. ==References== ==Other websites== * Everything I know I learned from Bob Dylan by Elizabeth Wurtzel * 1998 interview with Elizabeth Wurtzel by Gerald Peary * Sole Rock N Roll Survivor – Wurtzel's piece from The Harvard Crimson which won the 1987 Rolling Stone College Journalism Award * A Conversation with Elizabeth Wurtzel, Author and First-Year Lawyer October 11, 2008 blog post from WSJ.com * Category:American autobiographers Category:American feminist writers Category:1967 births Category:2020 deaths Category:Deaths from meningitis Category:Deaths from breast cancer Category:American essayists Category:Cancer deaths in New York City Category:Journalists from New York City
title: Elizabeth Wurtzel
